moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Bc5 4. c3 Nf6: Threatening the Q and unprotected White pawn on a2. Also protects the Black pawn on c6
moves.16. Qb1 Be6: Bringing another piece into the action with the aim of either 18...Bxa2 or 18...Bxf3. Also connects the rooks and extinguishes the possibility of Rxe8#
moves.17. a3 Nd5: Moving the knight back towards the centre. Will aim to bring the rooks into action soon.
moves.18. b4 Rac8: This is the first in a series of positional moves I'm aiming to put together. Next I will transfer the queen to the other side of the board via b6-d8 before shifting my knight to f4.
moves.19. Nc4 Qd8 20. Qc2 Nf4 21. Qd2 Nd5: Trying to keep the knight in the 16 inner squares. I will now work on getting pawns on the a-b-c files up the board.
moves.22. h3 b6 23. Qd3 Nf4 24. Qe3 Nd5: I've decided to play the patience card here and try not to do anything rash. If I see anything better later, I'll play it, but at this moment I'm happy to chew up some time. Depending on what White decides to play next, I may push b6-b5 to put pressure on the c4 knight.
moves.25. Qd2 b5 26. Nce5: A good move that makes my previous b5 push look silly.
moves.26... Nf6: keeping the knight in the middle of the board and freeing the diagonals for the bishop
moves.27. Nxc6: An even better move that forces the queen to be moved. I am now a pawn down on material.
moves.27... Qc7 28. Nce5 Qb7: with the aim of getting to a6 to attack the vulnerable white a-pawn
moves.29. Nd3 Qa6 30. Rca1 Rfe8 31. Nc5 Qc6 32: With the aim of trading off pieces and leading into the endgame.
